docs.lead_paragraph: Back home for the August recess, senators supporting health-care reform have been subject to heckling and worse, accused by some of marching the country toward socialism.
docs.abstract: All sides are up in arms about health care, but maybe it's the legislative branch that needs fixing.
docs.snippet: All sides are up in arms about health care, but maybe it's the legislative branch that needs fixing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Arlen Specter and his staff encountered more anger at a town-hall meeting in Lebanon, Pa., a week after emotional outbursts in Philadelphia.

headline.main: Anger at a Town Hall Meeting

docs.lead_paragraph: One striking thing about Senator Arlen Specter's town-hall-style meeting Tuesday in Lebanon, Pa., was the age of the people in the crowd.
docs.abstract: Older Americans are more opposed to a health care overhaul than younger ones, according to recent polls. But why?
docs.snippet: Older Americans are more opposed to a health care overhaul than younger ones, according to recent polls. But why?

docs.lead_paragraph: Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino's future with the program is in question in the wake of a report that he admitted to a sexual encounter with a woman in a local restaurant in 2003 and paid $3,000 to get an abortion.
docs.abstract: Will Louisville fire Rick Pitino in the wake of his admission that he had sex with a woman in 2003 and later paid for her to have an abortion?
docs.snippet: Will Louisville fire Rick Pitino in the wake of his admission that he had sex with a woman in 2003 and later paid for her to have an abortion?

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Marcia Angell is a senior lecturer in social medicine at Harvard Medical School and former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine. A longtime critic of the pharmaceutical industry, she has called for an end to market-driven delivery of health care in the United States. She spoke with freelance writer Anne Underwood.
docs.abstract: Dr. Marcia Angell, former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine and a longtime foe of for-profit medicine, on why she believes current proposals miss the mark.
docs.snippet: Dr. Marcia Angell, former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine and a longtime foe of for-profit medicine, on why she believes current proposals miss the mark.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wednesday's news is a long list of starts, stops and flashbacks, from new scrutiny at Karl Rove's role in firing U.S. attorney generals to President Obama's attempts to stabilize a volcanic health care debate. The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, is determining the next steps for economic recovery, and there are some posters circulating in Washington that have the White House less than happy.

headline.main: Early Word: Health Care, U.S. Attorneys and a New Justice Heads to the White House

docs.abstract: Health Care debate rages on, while there's a new look at Karl Rove.
